algorithms.encoding

Class Huffman

  • java.lang.Object
    • algorithms.encoding.Huffman

  • public class Huffman
extends java.lang.Object
    Huffman encoding is a compression algorithm that uses entropy and a prefix-free variable length code. 
     prefix-free variable length code (a.k.a. prefix code)
    -- No codeword is a prefix of any other codeword
    -- Prefix codes are uniquely decodable
   Example: 1, 10, 110,111

   Prefix-free coding:
    -- uses a symbol tree for all symbols of message
    -- usually the most frequently used symbols are at top of tree
    -- static algorithms have 3 phases for ENCODING
        (1) read source messages and calculate symbol frequency
        (2) build symbol code tree, optimized by frequency
        (3) encode messages using symbol codes
    -- static algorithms have 3 phases for DECODING:
        (1) read the stats of the source message
            (usually the stored symbol table or other means
            to create it)
        (2) build the code tree
        (3) decode the messages
    Huffman and Shannon-Fado attempt to assign shorter code words to more frequent symbols. Huffman assigns a symbol to each character based upon the frequency of that character in the text string. The algorithm creates a table of frequency of characters and converts those to variable length binary strings. The most frequent characters use the smallest binary strings. The compressed results are usually 20%-90% of the original size. From Cormen et al. "Introduction to algorithms": consider only prefix-codes, that is, codes in which no codeword is also a prefix of some other codeword. Encoding for any binary character code is a concatenation of the codewords representing each character of the file. For example, with the variable-length prefix code of Figure 16.3, we code the 3-character file abc as 0.101.100, where “.” denotes concatenation. Prefix codes are desirable because they simplify decoding. Since no codeword is a prefix of any other, the codeword that begins an encoded file is unambiguous. We can simply identify the initial codeword, translate it back to the original character, and repeat the decoding process on the remainder of the encoded file. In our example, the string 001011101 parses uniquely as 0 . 0 . 101 . 1101, which decodes to aabe.
    Author:
    nichole

    • Method Detail

      • compress

        public Huffman.HuffmanEncoding compress(java.lang.String c)
        use Huffman encoding to compress the text s. returns a tree representing the compressed text and the frequency table needed to decode it. The runtime complexity is O(n * log_2 log_2 (n)) where n is the length of the text string c, though can be as high as O(n * log_2(n)) if Fibonacci heap is used.
        Parameters:
        c - text to encode
        Returns:
        returns the Huffman encoded text and the symbol code map.

      • buildFrequencyCodeTree

        protected HeapNode buildFrequencyCodeTree(gnu.trove.map.TIntIntMap f,
                                          int sumF)
        Parameters:
        f - map with key=code-point, value=frequency of code-point in original text.
        sumF - the sum of all frequencies in f. it's used to assign a maximum bit-length needed by an internal YFastTrie data structure.
        Returns:

      • buildSymbolCodeTree

        protected Huffman.EncodingSymbols buildSymbolCodeTree(gnu.trove.map.TIntIntMap f,
                                                      int sumF)
        Parameters:
        f - map with key=code-point, value=frequency of code-point in original text.
        sumF - the sum of all frequencies in f. it's used to assign a maximum bit-length needed by an internal YFastTrie data structure.
        Returns:

      • encode

        VeryLongBitString encode(java.lang.String c,
                         gnu.trove.map.TIntIntMap codeSymbolMap)
        encode the text c, given the code symbol map.
        Parameters:
        c - uncoded text to be encoded.
        codeSymbolMap - map with key = alphabet code point, value = bit-string symbol.
        Returns:
        returns the encoding of text 'c', stored as a VeryLongBitString.

      • decompress

        public java.lang.String decompress(HeapNode symbolTree,
                                   VeryLongBitString encoded)
        decode the Huffman encoded tree. runtime complexity is O(N) where N is the number of characters in the original text.
        Parameters:
        symbolTree - the symbol code map
        encoded - text
        Returns:
        returns the decoded text.
